conclusion: Use Faraday's Law to find the maximum induced EMF.
Magnetic flux through the loop is given by Φ = B ⋅ A.
Area of the loop within the magnetic field changes as the loop enters the field.
Side length of the equilateral triangle is a.
When point D reaches MN, area within the magnetic field is zero.
As point C moves into the field, area within the field increases.
Area A of the triangle in the field is A = (1/2) ⋅ x ⋅ (√3/2)a.
Rate of change of area is dA/dt = (1/2) ⋅ (√3/2)a ⋅ v.
Substitute rate of change of area: 𝓔 = -B ⋅ ((1/2) ⋅ (√3/2)a ⋅ v).
Simplify to get 𝓔 = -(√3/4) B a v.
Maximum EMF occurs when entire loop is within the field.
Maximum induced EMF is 𝓔_max = (√3/4) B a v.
Final answer: Maximum EMF is (√3/4) B a v.
